div.head: ACT I .
THE HALL OF WYNNSTAY HOUSE .
div.stage: Illustration : Stage setting . ] Twelve o'clock Sunday morning at end of June . Action takes place between twelve and six same day . VOTES FOR WOMEN ACT I HALL OF WYNNSTAY HOUSE . Twelve o'clock , Sunday morning , end of June . With the rising of the Curtain , enter the BUTLER . As he is going , with majestic port , to answer the door L ., enter briskly from the garden , by lower French window , LADY JOHN WYNNSTAY , flushed , and flapping a garden hat to fan herself . She is a pink-cheeked woman of fifty-four , who has plainly been a beauty , keeps her complexion , but is “ gone to fat . ”

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Has Miss Levering come down yet ? BUTLERpausing C .I have n't seen her , m'lady . LADY JOHNalmost sharply as BUTLER turns L .I wo n't have her disturbed if she 's resting .To herself as she goes to writing-table .She certainly needs it .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Yes , m'lady . LADY JOHNsitting at writing-table , her back to front doorBut I want her to know the moment she comes down that the new plans arrived by the morning post . BUTLERpausing nearly at the doorPlans , m'la ——

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: She 'll understand . There they are .Glancing at the clock .It 's very important she should have them in time to look over before she goes ——

div.stage: BUTLER opens the door L .
Over her shoulder . ) Is that Miss Levering ?

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: No , m'lady . Mr. Farnborough .

div.stage: Exit BUTLER .
Enter the HON . R. FARNBOROUGH . He is twenty-six ; reddish hair , high-coloured , sanguine , self-important .

sp.speaker: FARNBOROUGH
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 'm scandalously early . It did n't take me nearly as long to motor over as Lord John said . LADY JOHNshaking handsI 'm afraid my husband is no authority on motoring — and he 's not home yet from church .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: It 's the greatest luck finding you . I thought Miss Levering was the only person under this roof who was ever allowed to observe Sunday as a real Day of Rest .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: If you 've come to see Miss Levering ——

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Is she here ? I give you my word I did n't know it . LADY JOHNunconvincedOh ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Does she come every week-end ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Whenever we can get her to . But we 've only known her a couple of months .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: And I have only known her three weeks ! Lady John , I 've come to ask you to help me . LADY JOHNquicklyWith Miss Levering ? I can n't do it !

lg.l: No , no — all that 's no good . She only laughs .
Ah !— she looks upon you as a boy .
Such rot ! What do you think she said to me in

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: That she was four years older than you ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Oh , I knew that . No . She said she knew she was all the charming things I 'd been saying , but there was only one way to prove it — and that was to marry some one young enough to be her son . She 'd noticed that was what the most attractive women did — and she named names . LADY JOHNlaughingYou were too old !

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: nodsHer future husband , she said , was probably just entering Eton .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Just like her !

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: waving the subject awayNo . I wanted to see you about the Secretaryship .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: You did n't get it , then ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: No . It 's the grief of my life .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Oh , if you do n't get one you 'll get another .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: But there is only one .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Only one vacancy ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Only one man I 'd give my ears to work for . LADY JOHNsmilingI remember .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: quicklyDo I always talk about Stonor ? Well , it 's a habit people have got into .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: I forget , do you know Mr. Stonor personally , orsmilingare you just dazzled from afar ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Oh , I know him . The trouble is he does n't know me . If he did he 'd realise he can n't be sure of winning his election without my valuable services .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Geoffrey Stonor 's re-election is always a foregone conclusion .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: That the great man shares that opinion is precisely his weak point .Smiling .His only one .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: You think because the Liberals swept the country the last time ——

lg.l: How can we be sure any Conservative seat is safe after ——
lg.stage: As LADY JOHN smiles and turns to her papers .
lg.l: Forgive me , I know you 're not interested in politics qua politics .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: And you count on my being interested in him like all the rest of my sex .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: leans forwardLady John , I 've heard the news .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: What news ?

lg.l: That your little niece — the Scotch heiress — is going to become

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Who told you that ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Please do n't mind my knowing . LADY JOHNvisibly perturbedShe had set her heart upon having a few days with just her family in the secret , before the flood of congratulations breaks loose .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Oh , that 's all right . I always hear things before other people .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Well , I must ask you to be good enough to be very circumspect . I would n't have my niece think that I ——

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Oh , of course not .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: She will be here in an hour .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: jumping up delightedWhat ? To-day ? The future Mrs. Stonor ! LADY JOHNharassedYes . Unfortunately we had one or two people already asked for the week-end ——

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: And I go and invite myself to luncheon ! Lady John , you can buy me off . I 'll promise to remove myself in five minutes if you 'll ——

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: No , the penalty is you shall stay and keep the others amused between church and luncheon , and so leave me free .Takes up the plan .Only remember ——

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Wild horses wo n't get a hint out of me ! I only mentioned it to you because — since we 've come back to live in this part of the world you 've been so awfully kind — I thought , I hoped maybe you — you 'd put in a word for me .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: With ——?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: With your nephew that is to be . Though I 'm not the slavish satellite people make out , you can n't doubt ——

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Oh , I do n't doubt . But you know Mr. Stonor inspires a similar enthusiasm in a good many young ——

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: They have n't studied the situation as I have . They do n't know what 's at stake . They do n't go to that hole Dutfield as I did just to hear his Friday speech .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Ah ! But you were rewarded . Jean — my niece — wrote me it was “ glorious . ”

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: judiciallyWell , you know , I was disappointed . He 's too content just to criticise , just to make his delicate pungent fun of the men who are grappling — very inadequately , of course — still grappling with the big questions . There 's a carrying powergets up and faces an imaginary audience— some of Stonor 's friends ought to point it out — there 's a driving power in the poorest constructive policy that makes the most brilliant criticism look barren . LADY JOHNwith good-humoured maliceWho told you that ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: You think there 's nothing in it because I say it . But now that he 's coming into the family , Lord John or somebody really ought to point out — Stonor 's overdoing his role of magnificent security !

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: I do n't see even Lord John offering to instruct Mr. Stonor .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Believe me , that 's just Stonor 's danger ! Nobody saying a word , everybody hoping he 's on the point of adopting some definite line , something strong and original that 's going to fire the public imagination and bring the Tories back into power .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: So he will .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: hotlyNot if he disappoints meetings — goes calmly up to town — and leaves the field to the Liberals .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: When did he do anything like that ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Yesterday !With a harassed air .And now that he 's got this other preoccupation ——

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: You mean ——

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Yes , your niece — that spoilt child of Fortune . Of course !Stopping suddenly .She kept him from the meeting last night . Well !sits downif that 's the effect she 's going to have it 's pretty serious ! LADY JOHNsmilingYou are !

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: I can assure you the election agent 's more so . He 's simply tearing his hair . LADY JOHNmore gravely and coming nearerHow do you know ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: He told me so himself — yesterday . I scraped acquaintance with the agent just to see if — if ——

lg.l: It 's not only here that you manoeuvre for that

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: confidentiallyYou can never tell when your chance might come ! That election chap 's promised to keep me posted .

div.stage: The door flies open and JEAN DUNBARTON rushes in .
They embrace . Enter LORD JOHN from the garden — a benevolent , silver-haired despot of sixty-two .

sp.speaker: LORD JOHN
sp.p: I thought that was you running up the avenue .

div.stage: JEAN greets her uncle warmly , but all the time she and her aunt talk together . “ How did you get here so early ? ” “ I knew you 'd be surprised — was n't it clever of me to manage it ? I do n't deserve all the credit . ” “ But there is n't any train between —— ” “ Yes , wait till I tell you . ” “ You walked in the broiling sun —— ” “ No , no . ” “ You must be dead . Why did n't you telegraph ? I ordered the carriage to meet the 1. 10 . Did n't you say the 1. 10 ? Yes , I 'm sure you did — here 's your letter . ”

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: has shaken hands with FARNBOROUGH and speaks through the torrentNow they 'll tell each other for ten minutes that she 's an hour earlier than we expected .

div.stage: LORD JOHN leads FARNBOROUGH towards the garden .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: The Freddy Tunbridges said they were coming to you this week .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Yes , they 're dawdling through the park with the Church Brigade .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Oh !With a glance back at JEAN .I 'll go and meet them .

div.stage: Exit FARNBOROUGH .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: as he turns backThat discreet young man will get on . LADY JOHNto JEANBut how did you get here ? JEANbreathless“ He ” motored me down .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Geoffrey Stonor ?JEAN nods .Why , where is he , then ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: He dropped me at the end of the avenue and went on to see a supporter about something .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: You let him go off like that without —— LADY JOHNtaking JEAN 'S two handsJust tell me , my child , is it all right ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: My engagement ?Radiantly .Yes , absolutely .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Geoffrey Stonor is n't going to be — a little too old for you ? JEANlaughingBless me , am I such a chicken ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Twenty-four used not to be so young — but it 's become so .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Yes , we do n't grow up so quick .Gaily .But on the other hand we stay up longer .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: You 've got what 's vulgarly called “ looks , ” my dear , and that will help to keep you up ! JEANsmilingI know what Uncle John 's thinking . But I 'm not the only girl who 's been left “ what 's vulgarly called ” money .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: You 're the only one of our immediate circle who 's been left so beautifully much .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Ah , but remember Geoffrey could — everybody knows he could have married any one in England . LADY JOHNfaintly ironicI 'm afraid everybody does know it — not excepting Mr. Stonor .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Well , how spoilt is the great man ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Not the least little bit in the world . You 'll see ! He so wants to know my best-beloved relations better .Another embrace .An orphan has so few belongings , she has to make the most of them .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: smilingLet us hope he 'll approve of us on more intimate acquaintance . JEANfirmlyHe will . He 's an angel . Why , he gets on with my grandfather !

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Does he ?Teasing .You mean to say Mr. Geoffrey Stonor is n't just a tiny bit — “ superior ” about Dissenters . JEANstoutlyNot half as much as Uncle John and all the rest of you ! My grandfather 's been ill again , you know , and rather difficult — bless him !Radiantly .But Geoffrey ——Clasps her hands .

lg.l: He must have powers of persuasion !— to get that old
Covenanter to let you come in an abhorred motor-car — on Sunday , too !

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Did n't know ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I honestly meant to come by train . Geoffrey met me on my way to the station . We had the most glorious run . Oh , Aunt Ellen , we 're so happy !Embracing her .I 've so looked forward to having you to myself the whole day just to talk to you about ——

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: turning away with affected displeasureOh , very well —— JEANcatches him affectionately by the armYou 'd find it dreffly dull to hear me talk about Geoffrey the whole blessed day !

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Well , till luncheon , my dear , you must n't mind if I ——To LORD JOHN , as she goes to writing-table .Miss Levering was n't only tired last night , she was ill .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: I thought she looked very white .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Who is Miss —— You do n't mean to say there are other people ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: One or two . Your uncle 's responsible for asking that old cynic , St. John Greatorex , and I —— JEANgravelyMr. Greatorex — he 's a Radical , is n't he ?

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: laughingJean ! Beginning to “ think in parties ” !

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: It 's very natural now that she should ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I only meant it was odd he should be here . Naturally at my grandfather 's ——

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: It 's all right , my child . Of course we expect now that you 'll begin to think like Geoffrey Stonor , and to feel like Geoffrey Stonor , and to talk like Geoffrey Stonor . And quite proper too . JEANsmilingWell , if I do think with my husband and feel with him — as , of course , I shall — it will surprise me if I ever find myself talking a tenth as well ——Following her uncle to the French window .You should have heard him at Dutfield ——Stopping short , delighted .Oh ! The Freddy Tunbridges . What ? Not Aunt Lydia ! Oh-h !

div.stage: Looking back reproachfully at LADY JOHN , who makes a discreet motion “ I could n't help it . ”

Enter the TUNBRIDGES . MR. FREDDY , of no profession and of independent means . Well-groomed , pleasant-looking ; of few words . A “ nice man ” who likes “ nice women ” and has married one of them . MRS. FREDDY is thirty . An attractive figure , delicate face , intelligent grey eyes , over-sensitive mouth , and naturally curling dust-coloured hair .

sp.speaker: MRS. FREDDY
sp.p: What a delightful surprise ! JEANshaking hands warmlyI 'm so glad . How d'ye do , Mr. Freddy ?

div.stage: Enter LADY JOHN 'S sister , MRS. HERIOT — smart , pompous , fifty — followed by FARNBOROUGH .

sp.speaker: MRS. HERIOT
sp.p: My dear Jean ! My darling child !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: How do you do , aunt ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: sotto voceI was n't surprised . I always prophesied ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Sh ! Please !

lg.l: We have n't met since you were in short skirts . I 'm Dick

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh , I remember .

div.stage: They shake hands .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: looking roundNot down yet — the Elusive One ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Who is the Elusive One ?

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Lady John 's new friend .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: to JEANOh , I forgot you had n't seen Miss Levering ; such a nice creature !To MRS. FREDDY .— do n't you think ?

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Of course I do . You 're lucky to get her to come so often . She wo n't go to other people .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: She knows she can rest here . FREDDYwho has joined LADY JOHN near the writing-tableWhat does she do to tire her ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: She 's been helping my sister and me with a scheme of ours .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: She certainly knows how to inveigle money out of the men .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: It would sound less equivocal , Lydia , if you added that the money is to build baths in our Shelter for Homeless Women .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Homeless women ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Yes , in the most insanitary part of Soho .

sp.speaker: FREDDY
sp.p: Oh — a — really .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: It does n't sound quite in Miss Levering 's line !

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: My dear boy , you know as little about what 's in a woman 's line as most men . FREDDYlaughingOh , I say !

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: indulgently to MR. FREDDY and FARNBOROUGHPhilanthropy in a woman like Miss Levering is a form of restlessness . But she 's a nice creature ; all she needs is to get some “ nice ” fella to marry her .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: laughing as she hangs on her husband 's armYes , a woman needs a balance wheel — if only to keep her from flying back to town on a hot day like this .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Who 's proposing anything so ——

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: The Elusive One .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Not Miss ——

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Yes , before luncheon !

div.stage: Exit FARNBOROUGH to garden .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: She must be in London by this afternoon , she says .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: What for in the name of ——

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Well , that I did n't ask her . Butconsults watchI think I 'll just go up and see if she 's changed her plans .

div.stage: Exit LADY JOHN .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Oh , she must be made to . Such a nice creature ! All she needs ——

div.stage: Voices outside . Enter fussily , talking and gesticulating , ST. JOHN GREATOREX , followed by MISS LEVERING and FARNBOROUGH . GREATOREX is sixty , wealthy , a county magnate , and Liberal M. P . He is square , thick-set , square-bearded . His shining bald pate has two strands of coal-black hair trained across his crown from left ear to right and securely pasted there . He has small , twinkling eyes and a reputation for telling good stories after dinner when ladies have left the room . He is carrying a little book for MISS LEVERING . She ( parasol over shoulder ) , an attractive , essentially feminine , and rather “ smart ” woman of thirty-two , with a somewhat foreign grace ; the kind of whom men and women alike say , “ What 's her story ? Why does n't she marry ? ”

sp.speaker: GREATOREX
sp.p: I protest ! Good Lord ! what are the women of this country coming to ? I protest against Miss Levering being carried off to discuss anything so revolting . Bless my soul ! what can a woman like you know about it ? MISS LEVERINGsmilingLittle enough . Good morning .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: relievedI should think so indeed !

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: asideYou are n't serious about going ——

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: waggishly breaking inWe were so happy out there in the summer-house , were n't we ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Ideally .

lg.l: And to be haled out to talk about Public Sanitation forsooth !
lg.stage: Hurries after MISS LEVERING as she advances to speak to the FREDDYS , & c .
lg.l: Why , God bless my soul , do you realise that 's drains ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I 'm dreadfully afraid it is !Holds out her hand for the small book GREATOREX is carrying .

div.stage: GREATOREX returns MISS LEVERING 'S book open ; he has been keeping the place with his finger . She opens it and shuts her handkerchief in .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: And we in the act of discussing Italian literature ! Perhaps you 'll tell me that is n't a more savoury topic for a lady .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: But for the tramp population less conducive to savouriness , do n't you think , than — baths ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: No , I can n't understand this morbid interest in vagrants . You 're much too — leave it to the others .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: What others ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: with smiling impertinenceOh , the sort of woman who smells of indiarubber . The typical English spinster .To MISS LEVERING .You know — Italy 's full of her . She never goes anywhere without a mackintosh and a collapsible bath — rubber . When you look at her , it 's borne in upon you that she does n't only smell of rubber . She 's rubber too .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: laughingThis is my niece , Miss Jean Dunbarton , Miss Levering .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: How do you do ?They shake hands .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: to JEANI 'm sure you agree with me .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: About Miss Levering being too ——

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: For that sort of thing — much too ——

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: What a pity you 've exhausted the more eloquent adjectives .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: But I have n't !

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Well , you can n't say to me as you did to Mrs. Freddy : “ You 're too young and too happily married — and too —— ”

div.stage: Glances round smiling at MRS. FREDDY , who , oblivious , is laughing and talking to her husband and MRS. HERIOT .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: For what was Mrs. Freddy too happily married and all the rest ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: lightlyMr. Greatorex was repudiating the horrid rumour that Mrs. Freddy had been speaking in public ; about Women 's Trade Unions — was n't that what you said , Mrs. Heriot ?

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: chucklingYes , it is n't made up as carefully as your aunt 's parties usually are . Here we 've got Greatorextakes his armwho hates political women , and we 've got in that mild and inoffensive-looking little lady ——

div.stage: Motion over his shoulder towards MRS. FREDDY .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: shrinking down stage in comic terrorYou do n't mean she 's really —— JEANsimultaneously and gaily risingOh , and you 've got me !

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: with genial affectionMy dear child , he does n't hate the charming wives and sweethearts who help to win seats .

div.stage: JEAN makes her uncle a discreet little signal of warning .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Mr. Greatorex objects only to the unsexed creatures who — a ——

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: hastily to cover up his slipYes , yes , who want to act independently of men .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Vote , and do silly things of that sort .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: with enthusiasmExactly .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: It will be a long time before we hear any more of that nonsense .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: You mean that rowdy scene in the House of Commons ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Yes . No decent woman will be able to say “ Suffrage ” without blushing for another generation , thank Heaven !

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: smilingOh ? I understood that so little I almost imagined people were more stirred up about it than they 'd ever been before .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: with a quizzical affectation of gallantryNot people like you .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: teasinglyHow do you know ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: with a startGod bless my soul !

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: She 's saying that only to get a rise out of you .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Ah , yes , your frocks are n't serious enough .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I 'm told it 's an exploded notion that the Suffrage women are all dowdy and dull .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Do n't you believe it !

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Well , of course we know you 've been an authority on the subject for — let 's see , how many years is it you 've kept the House in roars whenever Woman 's Rights are mentioned ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: flattered but not entirely comfortableOh , as long as I 've known anything about politics there have been a few discontented old maids and hungry widows ——

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: “ A few ! ” That 's really rather forbearing of you , Mr. Greatorex . I 'm afraid the number of the discontented and the hungry was 96 , 000 — among the mill operatives alone .Hastily .At least the papers said so , did n't they ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Oh , do n't ask me ; that kind of woman does n't interest me , I 'm afraid . Only I am able to point out to the people who lose their heads and seem inclined to treat the phenomenon seriously that there 's absolutely nothing new in it . There have been women for the last forty years who have n't had anything more pressing to do than petition Parliament .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: reflectivelyAnd that 's as far as they 've got .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: turning on his heelIt 's as far as they 'll ever get .

div.stage: Meets the group up R. coming down .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: chaffing GREATOREXLet me see , was n't a deputation sent to you not long ago ?Sits C .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: H 'm !Irritably .Yes , yes .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: as though she has just recalled the circumstancesOh , yes , I remember . I thought at the time , in my modest way , it was nothing short of heroic of them to go asking audience of their arch opponent .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: stoutlyIt did n't come off .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: innocentlyOh ! I thought they insisted on bearding the lion in his den .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Of course I was n't going to be bothered with a lot of ——

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: You do n't mean you refused to go out and face them !

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: with a comic look of terrorI would n't have done it for worlds . But a friend of mine went and had a look at ‘ em .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: smilingWell , did he get back alive ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Yes , but he advised me not to go . “ You 're quite right , ” he said . “ Do n't you think of bothering , ” he said . “ I 've looked over the lot , ” he said , “ and there is n't a week-ender among ‘ em . ” JEANgaily precipitates herself into the conversationYou remember Mrs. Freddy 's friend who came to tea here in the winter ?To GREATOREX .He was a member of Parliament too — quite a little young one — he said women would never be respected till they had the vote !

div.stage: GREATOREX snorts , the other men smile and all the women except MRS. HERIOT .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: sniffingI remember telling him that he was too young to know what he was talking about .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Yes , I 'm afraid you all sat on the poor gentleman . LADY JOHNenteringOh , there you are !

div.stage: Greets MISS LEVERING .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: It was such fun . He was flat as a pancake when we 'd done with him . Aunt Ellen told him with her most distinguished air she did n't want to be “ respected . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: with a little laugh of remonstranceMy dear Lady John !

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Quite right ! Awful idea to think you 're respected !

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: smilingSimply revolting . LADY JOHNat writing-tableNow , you frivolous people , go away . We 've only got a few minutes to talk over the terms of the late Mr. Soper 's munificence before the carriage comes for Miss Levering ——

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: to FARNBOROUGHDid you know she 'd got that old horror to give Lady John L8 , 000 for her charity before he died ?

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Who got him to ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Miss Levering . He would n't do it for me , but she brought him round .

sp.speaker: FREDDY
sp.p: Yes . Bah-ee Jove ! I expect so .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: turning enthusiastically to her husbandIs n't she wonderful ?

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: asideNice creature . All she needs is ——

div.stage: MR. and MRS. FREDDY and FARNBOROUGH stroll off to the garden . LADY JOHN on far side of the writing-table . MRS. HERIOT at the top . JEAN and LORD JOHN , L .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: on divan C ., aside to MISS LEVERINGToo “ wonderful ” to waste your time on the wrong people .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I shall waste less of my time after this .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: I 'm relieved to hear it . I can n't see you wheedling money for shelters and rot of that sort out of retired grocers .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: You see , you call it rot . We could n't have got L8 , 000 out of you .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: very lowI 'm not sure .

div.stage: MISS LEVERING looks at him .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: If I gave you that much — for your little projects — what would you give me ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: speaking quietlySoper did n't ask that .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: horrifiedSoper ! I should think not !

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: turning to MISS LEVERINGSoper ? You two still talking Soper ? How flattered the old beggar 'd be !

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: lowerDid you hear what Mrs. Heriot said about him ? “ So kind ; so munificent — so vulgar , poor soul , we could n't know him in London — but we shall meet him in heaven . ”GREATOREX and LORD JOHN go off laughing .LADY JOHNto Miss LeveringSit over there , my dear .Indicating chair in front of writing-table .You need n't stay , Jean . This wo n't interest you .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: in the tone of one agreeingIt 's only an effort to meet the greatest evil in the world ? JEANpausing as she 's following the othersWhat do you call the greatest evil in the world ?Looks pass between MRS. HERIOT and LADY JOHN .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: without emphasisThe helplessness of women .JEAN stands still .LADY JOHNrising and putting her arm about the girl 's shoulderJean , darling , I know you can think of nothing butasidehim — so just go and —— JEANbrightlyIndeed , indeed , I can think of everything better than I ever did before . He has lit up everything for me — made everything vivider , more — more significant .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: turning roundWho has ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh , yes , I do n't care about other things less but a thousand times more .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: You are in love .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Oh , that 's it !Smiling at JEAN .I congratulate you . LADY JOHNreturning to the outspread planWell — this , you see , obviates the difficulty you raised .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Yes , quite .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: But it 's going to cost a great deal more .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: It 's worth it .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: We 'll have nothing left for the organ at St. Pilgrim 's .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: My dear Lydia , we 're putting the organ aside .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: with asperityWe can n't afford to “ put aside ” the elevating effect of music .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: What we must make for , first , is the cheap and humanely conducted lodging-house .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: There are several of those already , but poor St. Pilgrim 's ——

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: There are none for the poorest women .

lg.l: No , even the excellent Soper was for multiplying Rowton
Houses . You can never get men to realise — you can n't always get women ——

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: It 's the work least able to wait .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: I do n't agree with you , and I happen to have spent a great deal of my life in works of charity .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Ah , then you 'll be interested in the girl I saw dying in a Tramp Ward a little while ago . Glad her cough was worse — only she must n't die before her father . Two reasons . Nobody but her to keep the old man out of the workhouse — and “ father is so proud . ” If she died first , he would starve ; worst of all he might hear what had happened up in London to his girl .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: She did n't say , I suppose , how she happened to fall so low .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Yes , she had been in service . She lost the train back one Sunday night and was too terrified of her employer to dare ring him up after hours . The wrong person found her crying on the platform .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: She should have gone to one of the Friendly Societies .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: At eleven at night ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: And there are the Rescue Leagues . I myself have been connected with one for twenty years ——

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: reflectively“ Twenty years ! ” Always arriving “ after the train 's gone ” — after the girl and the Wrong Person have got to the journey 's end .

div.stage: MRS. HERIOT 's eyes flash .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Where is she now ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Never mind .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Two nights ago she was waiting at a street corner in the rain .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Near a public-house , I suppose .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Yes , a sort of “ public-house . ” She was plainly dying — she was told she should n't be out in the rain . “ I must n't go in yet , ” she said . “ This is what he gave me , ” and she began to cry . In her hand were two pennies silvered over to look like half-crowns .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: I do n't believe that story . It 's just the sort of thing some sensation-monger trumps up — now , who tells you such ——

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Several credible people . I did n't believe them till ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Till ——?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Till last week I saw for myself .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Saw ? Where ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: In a low lodging-house not a hundred yards from the church you want a new organ for .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: How did you happen to be there ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I was on a pilgrimage .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: A pilgrimage ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Into the Underworld .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: You went ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: How could you ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I put on an old gown and a tawdry hat ——Turns to LADY JOHN .You 'll never know how many things are hidden from a woman in good clothes . The bold , free look of a man at a woman he believes to be destitute — you must feel that look on you before you can understand — a good half of history .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: risesJean !——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: But where did you go — dressed like that ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Down among the homeless women — on a wet night looking for shelter . LADY JOHNhastilyNo wonder you 've been ill . JEANunder breathAnd it 's like that ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: No ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: It 's so much worse I dare not tell about it — even if you were n't here I could n't .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: to JEANYou need n't suppose , darling , that those wretched creatures feel it as we would .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: The girls who need shelter and work are n't all serving-maids .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: with an involuntary flashWe know that all the women who — make mistakes are n't .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: steadilyThat is why every woman ought to take an interest in this — every girl too . JEAN Yes — oh , yes !simultaneouslyLADY JOHN No . This is a matter for us older ——

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: with an air of sly challengeOr for a person who has some special knowledge .Significantly .We can n't pretend to have access to such sources of information as Miss Levering .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: meeting MRS. HERIOT 'S eye steadilyYes , for I can give you access . As you seem to think , I have some first-hand knowledge about homeless girls . LADY JOHNcheerfully turning it asideWell , my dear , it will all come in convenient .Tapping the plan .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: It once happened to me to take offence at an ugly thing that was going on under my father 's roof . Oh , years ago ! I was an impulsive girl . I turned my back on my father 's house —— LADY JOHNfor JEAN 'S benefitThat was ill-advised .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Of course , if a girl does that ——

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: That was what all my relations saidwith a glance at JEAN, and I could n't explain .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Not to your mother ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: She was dead . I went to London to a small hotel and tried to find employment . I wandered about all day and every day from agency to agency . I was supposed to be educated . I 'd been brought up partly in Paris ; I could play several instruments , and sing little songs in four different tongues .Slight pause .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Did nobody want you to teach French or sing the little songs ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: The heads of schools thought me too young . There were people ready to listen to my singing , but the terms — they were too hard . Soon my money was gone . I began to pawn my trinkets . They went .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: And still no work ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: No ; but by that time I had some real education — an unpaid hotel bill , and not a shilling in the world .Slight pause .Some girls think it hardship to have to earn their living . The horror is not to be allowed to ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: bending forwardWhat happened ? LADY JOHNrisesMy dearto MISS LEVERING, have your things been sent down ? Are you quite ready ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Yes , all but my hat .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Well , by chance I met a friend of my family .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: That was lucky .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I thought so . He was nearly ten years older than I . He said he wanted to help me .Pause .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: And did n't he ?

div.stage: LADY JOHN lays her hand on MISS LEVERING 'S shoulder .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Perhaps after all he did .With sudden change of tone .Why do I waste time over myself ? I belonged to the little class of armed women . My body was n't born weak , and my spirit was n't broken by the habit of slavery . But , as Mrs. Heriot was kind enough to hint , I do know something about the possible fate of homeless girls . I found there were pleasant parks , museums , free libraries in our great rich London — and not one single place where destitute women can be sure of work that is n't killing or food that is n't worse than prison fare . That 's why women ought not to sleep o ’ nights till this Shelter stands spreading out wide arms .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: No , no ——

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: gathering up her gloves , fan , prayer-book , & c .Even when it 's built — you 'll see ! Many of those creatures will prefer the life they lead . They like it .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: A woman told me — one of the sort that knows — told me many of them “ like it ” so much that they are indifferent to the risk of being sent to prison . “ It gives them a rest , ” she said .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: A rest !MISS LEVERING glances at the clock as she rises to go upstairs .LADY JOHN and MRS. HERIOT bend their heads over the plan , covertly talking .JEANintercepting MISS LEVERINGI want to begin to understand something of — I 'm horribly ignorant .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Looks at her searchinglyI 'm a rather busy person ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: interruptingI have a quite special reason for wanting not to be ignorant .ImpulsivelyI 'll go to town to-morrow , if you 'll come and lunch with me .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Thank you — Icatches MRS. HERIOT 'S eye— I must go and put my hat on .

div.stage: Exit upstairs .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: asideHow little she minds all these horrors !

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: They turn me cold . Ugh !Rising , harassed .I wonder if she 's signed the visitors ’ book !

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: For all her Shelter schemes , she 's a hard woman .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Miss Levering is ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Oh , of course you wo n't think so . She has angled very adroitly for your sympathy .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: She does n't look hard . LADY JOHNglancing at JEAN and taking alarmI 'm not sure but what she does . Her mouth — always like this ... as if she were holding back something by main force !

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: half under her breathWell , so she is .

div.stage: Exit LADY JOHN into the lobby to look at the visitors ’ book .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Why have n't I seen her before ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Oh , she 's lived abroad .Debating with herself .You do n't know about her , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I do n't know how Aunt Ellen came to know her .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: That was my doing . But I did n't bargain for her being introduced to you .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: She seems to go everywhere . And why should n't she ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: quicklyYou must n't ask her to Eaton Square .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I have .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Then you 'll have to get out of it . JEANwith a stubborn lookI must have a reason . And a very good reason .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Well , it 's not a thing I should have preferred to tell you , but I know how difficult you are to guide ... so I suppose you 'll have to know .Lowering her voice .It was ten or twelve years ago . I found her horribly ill in a lonely Welsh farmhouse . We had taken the Manor for that August . The farmer 's wife was frightened , and begged me to go and see what I thought . I soon saw how it was — I thought she was dying .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Dying ! What was the ——

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: I got no more out of her than the farmer 's wife did . She had had no letters . There had been no one to see her except a man down from London , a shady-looking doctor — nameless , of course . And then this result . The farmer and his wife , highly respectable people , were incensed . They were for turning the girl out .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh ! but ——

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Yes . Pitiless some of these people are ! I insisted they should treat the girl humanely , and we became friends ... that is , “ sort of . ” In spite of all I did for her ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: What did you do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: I — I 've told you , and I lent her money . No small sum either .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Has she never paid it back ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Oh , yes , after a time . But I always kept her secret — as much as I knew of it .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: But you 've been telling me !

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: That was my duty — and I never had her full confidence .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Was n't it natural she ——

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Well , all things considered , she might have wanted to tell me who was responsible .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh ! Aunt Lydia !

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: All she ever said was that she was ashamed —losing her temper and her fine feeling for the innocence of her auditor— ashamed that she “ had n't had the courage to resist ” — not the original temptation but the pressure brought to bear on her “ not to go through with it , ” as she said . JEANwrinkling her browsYou are being so delicate — I 'm not sure I understand .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: irritablyThe only thing you need understand is that she 's not a desirable companion for a young girl .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: When did you see her after — after ——

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: with a slight grimaceI met her last winter at the Bishop 's .Hurriedly .She 's a connection of his wife 's . They 'd got her to help with some of their work . Then she took hold of ours . Your aunt and uncle are quite foolish about her , and I 'm debarred from taking any steps , at least till the Shelter is out of hand .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I do rather wonder she can bring herself to talk about — the unfortunate women of the world .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: The effrontery of it !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Or ... the courage !Puts her hand up to her throat as if the sentence had caught there .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Even presumes to set me right ! Of course I do n't mind in the least , poor soul ... but I feel I owe it to your dead mother to tell you about her , especially as you 're old enough now to know something about life —— JEANslowly— and since a girl need n't be very old to suffer for her ignorance .Moves a little away .I felt she was rather wonderful .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Wonderful ! JEANpausingTo have lived through that when she was ... how old ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: risingOh , nineteen or thereabouts .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Five years younger than I . To be abandoned and to come out of it like this !

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: laying her hand on the girl 's shoulderIt was too bad to have to tell you such a sordid story to-day of all days .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: It is a very terrible story , but this was n't a bad time . I feel very sorry to-day for women who are n't happy .

div.stage: Motor horn heard faintly .
Jumping up . ) That 's Geoffrey !

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Mr. Stonor ! What makes you think ...?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Yes , yes . I 'm sure , I 'm sure ——

div.stage: Checks herself as she is flying off . Turns and sees LORD JOHN entering from the garden .
Motor horn louder .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Who do you think is motoring up the drive ? JEANcatching hold of himOh , dear ! how am I ever going to be able to behave like a girl who is n't engaged to the only man in the world worth marrying ?

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: You were expecting Mr. Stonor all the time !

lg.l: He promised he 'd come to luncheon if it was humanly possible ; but
I was afraid to tell you for fear he 'd be prevented .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: laughing as he crosses to the lobbyYou felt we could n't have borne the disappointment .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I felt I could n't .

div.stage: The lobby door opens . LADY JOHN appears radiant , followed by a tall figure in a dust-coat , & c ., no goggles . He has straight , firm features , a little blunt ; fair skin , high-coloured ; fine , straight hair , very fair ; grey eyes , set somewhat prominently and heavy when not interested ; lips full , but firmly moulded . GEOFFREY STONOR is heavier than a man of forty should be , but otherwise in the pink of physical condition . The FOOTMAN stands waiting to help him off with his motor coat .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Here 's an agreeable surprise !

div.stage: JEAN has gone forward only a step , and stands smiling at the approaching figure .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: How do you do ?As he comes between them and briskly shakes hands with STONOR .

div.stage: FARNBOROUGH appears at the French window .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Yes , by Jove !Turning to the others clustered round the window .What gigantic luck !

div.stage: Those outside crane and glance , and then elaborately turn their backs and pretend to be talking among themselves , but betray as far as manners permit the enormous sensation the arrival has created .

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: How do you do ?

div.stage: Shakes hands with MRS. HERIOT , who has rushed up to him with both hers outstretched . He crosses to JEAN , who meets him half way ; they shake hands , smiling into each other 's eyes .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Such a long time since we met !

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: to STONORYou 're growing very enterprising . I could hardly believe my ears when I heard you 'd motored all the way from town to see a supporter on Sunday .

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: I do n't know how we covered the ground in the old days .To LADY JOHN .It 's no use to stand for your borough any more . The American , you know , he “ runs ” for Congress . By and by we shall all be flying after the thing we want .

div.stage: Smiles at JEAN .

lg.stage: Smiles and then glances over her shoulder and speaks low .
lg.l: All sorts of irrelevant people here .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: unable to resist the temptation , comes forwardHow do you do , Mr. Stonor ?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Oh — how d'you do .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Some of them were arguing in the smoking-room last night whether it did n't hurt a man 's chances going about in a motor .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Yes , we 've been hearing a lot of stories about the unpopularity of motor-cars — among the class that has n't got ‘ em , of course . What do you say ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: I 'm sure you gain more votes by being able to reach so many more of your constituency than we used ——

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Well , I do n't know — I 've sometimes wondered whether the charm of our presence was n't counterbalanced by the way we tear about smothering our fellow-beings in dust and running down their pigs and chickens , not to speak of their children .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: anxiouslyWhat on the whole are the prospects ?FARNBOROUGH cranes forward .STONORgravelyWe shall have to work harder than we realised .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: Ah !Retires towards group .JEANin a half-aside as she slips her arm in her uncle 's and smiles at GEOFFREYHe says he believes I 'll be able to make a real difference to his chances . Is n't it angelic of him ? STONORin a jocular toneAngelic ? Macchiavelian . I pin all my hopes on your being able to counteract the pernicious influence of my opponent 's glib wife .

lg.l: You want me to have a real share in it all , do n't you ,

div.stage: FARNBOROUGH drops down again on pretence of talking to MRS. HERIOT .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: I do n't gather you 're altogether sanguine . Any complication ?

div.stage: JEAN and LADY JOHN stand close together ( C .) , the girl radiant , following STONOR with her eyes and whispering to the sympathetic elder woman .

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Welltaking Sunday paper out of pocket, there 's this agitation about the Woman Question . Oddly enough , it seems likely to affect the issue .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Why should it ? Ca n't you do what the other four hundred have done ? STONORlaughsEasily . But , you see , the mere fact that four hundred and twenty members have been worried into promising support — and then once in the House have let the matter severely alone ——

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: to STONORLet it alone ! Bless my soul , I should think so indeed .

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Of course . Only it 's a device that 's somewhat worn .

div.stage: Enter MISS LEVERING , with hat on ; gloves and veil in her hand .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Still if they think they 're getting a future Cabinet Minister on their side ——

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: it will be sufficiently embarrassing for the Cabinet Minister .STONOR turns to speak to JEAN . Stops dead seeing MISS LEVERING .JEANsmilingYou know one another ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: looking at STONOR with intentness but quite calmlyEverybody in this part of the world knows Mr. Stonor , but he does n't know me .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Miss Levering .They bow .Enter GREATOREX , sidling in with an air of giving MRS. FREDDY a wide berth .JEANto MISS LEVERING with artless enthusiasmOh , have you been hearing him speak ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Yes , I was visiting some relations near Dutfield . They took me to hear you .

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Oh — the night the Suffragettes made their customary row .

lg.stage: flying at the first chance of distraction , shakes hands with MRS. FREDDY
lg.l: Well , Mrs. Freddy , what do you think of your friends now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: My friends ? STONORoffering her the Sunday paperYes , the disorderly women .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: with dignityThey are not my friends , but I do n't think you must call them ——

lg.l: I can forgive them for worrying the late

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: quietlyIs n't the phrase consecrated to a different class ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: who has got hold of the Sunday paperHe 's perfectly right . How do you do ? Disorderly women ! That 's what they are !

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: reading over his shoulderOught to be locked up ! every one of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: assenting angrilyPublic nuisances ! Going about with dog whips and spitting in policemen 's faces .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: with a harassed airI wonder if they did spit ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: exultingOf course they did .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: turns on himYou 're no authority on what they do . You run away .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: trying to turn the laughRun away ? Yes .Backing a few paces .And if ever I muster up courage to come back , it will be to vote for better manners in public life , not worse than we have already .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: meeklySo should I . Do n't think that I defend the Suffragette methods .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: with cheerful curiosityStill , you are an advocate of the Suffrage , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Here ?Shrugs .I do n't beat the air .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: mockingOnly policemen .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: plaintivelyIf you cared to know the attitude of the real workers in the reform , you might have noticed in any paper last week we lost no time in dissociating ourselves from the little group of hysterical ——Catches her husband 's eye , and instantly checks her flow of words .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: They have lowered the whole sex in the eyes of the entire world . JEANjoining GEOFFREY STONORI can n't quite see what they want — those Suffragettes .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Notoriety .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: What they want ? A good thrashin ’ — that 's what I 'd give ‘ em .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: murmursSpirited fellow !

lg.l: Well , there 's one sure thing — they 've dished their goose .
lg.stage: GREATOREX chuckles , still reading the account .
lg.l: I believe these silly scenes are a pure joy to you .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Final death-blow to the whole silly business ! JEANmystified , looking from one to the otherThe Suffragettes do n't seem to know they 're dead .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: They still keep up a sort of death-rattle . But they 've done for themselves . JEANclasping her hands with fervourOh , I hope they 'll last till the election 's over .

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: staresWhy ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh , we want them to get the working man to —stumbling and a little confused— to vote for ... the Conservative candidate . Is n't that so ?

div.stage: Looking round for help . General laughter .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: Fancy , Jean ——!

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: The working man 's a good deal of an ass , but even he wo n't listen to —— JEANagain appealing to the silent STONORBut he does listen like anything ! I asked why there were so few at the Long Mitcham meeting , and I was told , “ Oh , they 've all gone to hear Miss —— ”

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Just for a lark , that was .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: It has no real effect on the vote .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Not the smallest . JEANwide-eyed , to STONORWhy , I thought you said —— STONORhastily , rubbing his hand over the lower part of his face and speaking quicklyI 've a notion a little soap and water would n't do me any harm .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: I 'll take you up . You know Freddy Tunbridge .STONOR pauses to shake hands . Exeunt all three .JEANperplexed , as STONOR turns away , says to GREATOREXWell , if women are of no importance in politics , it is n't for the reason you gave . There is now and then a week-ender among them .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: shuffles about uneasilyHm — Hm .Finds himself near MRS. FREDDY .Lord ! The perils that beset the feet of man !With an air of comic caution , moves away , L .JEANto FARNBOROUGH , aside , laughingWhy does he behave like that ?

sp.speaker: FARN
sp.p: His moral sense is shocked .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Why , I saw him and Mrs. Freddy together at the French Play the other night — as thick as thieves .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Ah , that was before he knew her revolting views .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: What revolting views ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Sh ! Sunday .As GREATOREX sidles cautiously further away .JEANlaughing in spite of herselfI can n't believe women are so helpless when I see men so afraid of them .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: The great mistake was in teaching them to read and write . JEANover MISS LEVERING 'S shoulder , whispersSay something .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: to GREATOREX , smilingOh no , that was n't the worst mistake .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Yes , it was .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: No . Believe me . The mistake was in letting women learn to talk .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Ah !Wheels about with sudden rapture .I see now what 's to be the next great reform .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: holding up the little volumeWhen women are all dumb , no more discussions of the “ Paradiso . ”

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: with a gesture of mock raptureThe thing itself !Aside .That 's a great deal better than talking about it , as I 'm sure you know .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Why do you think I know ?

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Only the plain women are in any doubt .

div.stage: JEAN joins MISS LEVERING .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: Wait for me , Farnborough . I cannot go about unprotected .

div.stage: Exeunt FARNBOROUGH and GREATOREX .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: It 's true what that old cynic says . The scene in the House has put back the reform a generation .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I wish ‘ d been there .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: I was .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh , was it like the papers said ?

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Worse . I 've never been so moved in public . No tragedy , no great opera ever gripped an audience as the situation in the House did that night . There we all sat breathless — with everything more favourable to us than it had been within the memory of women . Another five minutes and the Resolution would have passed . Then ... all in a moment —— LADY JOHNto MRS. HERIOTListen — they 're talking about the female hooligans .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: No , thank you !Sits apart with the “ Church Times . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: excitedlyAll in a moment a horrible dingy little flag was poked through the grille of the Woman 's Gallery — cries — insults — scuffling — the police — the ignominious turning out of the women — us as well as the —— Oh , I can n't think of it without ——

div.stage: Jumps up and walks to and fro .

Pauses . ) Then the next morning ! The people gloating . Our friends antagonised — people who were wavering — nearly won over — all thrown back — heart breaking ! Even my husband ! Freddy 's been an angel about letting me take my share when I felt I must — but of course I 've always known he does n't really like it . It makes him shy . I 'm sure it gives him a horrid twist inside when he sees my name among the speakers on the placards . But he 's always been an angel about it before this . After the disgraceful scene he said , “ It just shows how unfit women are for any sort of coherent thinking or concerted action . ”

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: To think that it should be women who 've given the Cause the worst blow it ever had !

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: The work of forty years destroyed in five minutes !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: They must have felt pretty sick when they woke up the next morning — the Suffragettes .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: I do n't waste any sympathy on them . I 'm thinking of the penalty all women have to pay because a handful of hysterical ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Still I think I 'm sorry for them . It must be dreadful to find you 've done such a lot of harm to the thing you care most about in the world .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Do you picture the Suffragettes sitting in sackcloth ?

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Well , they can n't help realising now what they 've done .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: quietlyIs n't it just possible they realise they 've waked up interest in the Woman Question so that it 's advertised in every paper and discussed in every house from Land 's End to John o'Groats ? Do n't you think they know there 's been more said and written about it in these ten days since the scene , than in the ten years before it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: You are n't saying you think it was a good way to get what they wanted ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: shrugsI 'm only pointing out that it seems not such a bad way to get it known they do want something — andsmiling“ want it bad . ” JEANgetting upDid n't Mr. Greatorex say women had been politely petitioning Parliament for forty years ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: And men have only laughed .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: But they 'd come round .She looks from one to the other .Mrs. Tunbridge says , before that horrid scene , everything was favourable at last .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: At last ? Had n't it been just as “ favourable ” before ?

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: No . We 'd never had so many members pledged to our side .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I thought I 'd heard somebody say the Bill had got as far as that , time and time again .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh no . Surely not ——

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: reluctantlyY-yes . This was only a Resolution . The Bill passed a second reading thirty-seven years ago . JEANwith wide eyesAnd what difference did it make ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: The men laughed rather louder .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Oh , it 's got as far as a second reading several times — but we never had so many friends in the House before ——

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: with a faint smile“ Friends ! ”

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Why do you say it like that ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Perhaps because I was thinking of a funny story — he said it was funny — a Liberal Whip told me the other day . A Radical Member went out of the House after his speech in favour of the Woman 's Bill , and as he came back half an hour later , he heard some Members talking in the Lobby about the astonishing number who were going to vote for the measure . And the Friend of Woman dropped his jaw and clutched the man next him : “ My God ! ” he said , “ you do n't mean to say they 're going to give it to them ! ”

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: You do n't think all men in Parliament are like that !

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I do n't think all men are burglars , but I lock my doors . JEANbelow her breathYou think that night of the scene — you think the men did n't mean to play fair ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: her coolness in contrast to the excitement of the othersDid n't the women sit quiet till ten minutes to closing time ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Ten minutes to settle a question like that !

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: quietly to MRS. FREDDYCould n't you see the men were at their old game ? LADY JOHNcoming forwardYou think they were just putting off the issue till it was too late ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: in a detached toneI was n't there , but I have n't heard anybody deny that the women waited till ten minutes to eleven . Then they discovered the policeman who 'd been sent up at the psychological moment to the back of the gallery . Then , I 'm told , when the women saw they were betrayed once more , they utilised the few minutes left , to impress on the country at large the fact of their demands — did it in the only way left them .Sits leaning forward reflectively smiling , chin in hand .It does rather look to the outsider as if the well-behaved women had worked for forty years and made less impression on the world then those fiery young women made in five minutes .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Oh , come , be fair !

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Well , you must admit that , next day , every newspaper reader in Europe and America knew there were women in England in such dead earnest about the Suffrage that the men had stopped laughing at last , and turned them out of the House . Men even advertised how little they appreciated the fun by sending the women to gaol in pretty sober earnest . And all the world was talking about it .

div.stage: MRS. HERIOT lays down the “ Church Times ” and joins the others .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: I have noticed , whenever the men are n't there , the women sit and discuss that scene . JEANcheerfullyI sha n't have to wait till the men are gone .Leans over LADY JOHN 'S shoulder and says half asideHe 's in sympathy .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: How do you know ?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: He told the interrupting women so .

div.stage: MRS. FREDDY looks mystified . The others smile .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: MR. FREDDY and LORD JOHN appear by the door they went out of . They stop to talk .

sp.speaker: MRS. F
sp.p: Here 's Freddy !Lower , hastily to MISS LEVERING .You 're judging from the outside . Those of us who have been working for years ... we all realise it was a perfectly lunatic proceeding . Why , think ! The only chance of our getting what we want is by winning over the men .Her watchful eye , leaving her husband for a moment , catches MISS LEVERING 'S little involuntary gesture .What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: “ Winning over the men ” has been the woman 's way for centuries . Do you think the result should make us proud of our policy ? Yes ? Then go and walk in Piccadilly at midnight .The older women glance at JEAN .No , I forgot ——

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: with majestyYes , it 's not the first time you 've forgotten .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I forgot the magistrate 's ruling . He said no decent woman had any business to be in London 's main thoroughfare at night unless she has a man with her . I heard that in Nine Elms , too . “ You 're obliged to take up with a chap ! ” was what the woman said .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: risingJEAN ! Come !She takes JEAN by her arm and draws her to the window , where she signals GREATOREX and FARNBOROUGH . MRS. FREDDY joins her husband and LORD JOHN .LADY JOHNkindly , aside to MISS LEVERINGMy dear , I think Lydia Heriot 's right . We ought n't to do anything or say anything to encourage this ferment of feminism , and I 'll tell you why : it 's likely to bring a very terrible thing in its train .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: What terrible thing ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Sex antagonism .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: risingIt 's here . LADY JOHNvery gravelyDo n't say that .

div.stage: JEAN has quietly disengaged herself from MRS. HERIOT , and the group at the window returns and stands behind LADY JOHN , looking up into MISS LEVERINGS 'S face .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: to LADY JOHNYou 're so conscious it 's here , you 're afraid to have it mentioned . LADY JOHNturning and seeing JEAN . Rising hastilyIf it 's here , it is the fault of those women agitators .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: gentlyNo woman begins that way .Leans forward with clasped hands looking into vacancy .Every woman 's in a state of natural subjectionsmiles at JEAN— no , I 'd rather say allegiance to her idea of romance and her hope of motherhood . They 're embodied for her in man . They 're the strongest things in life — till man kills them .Rousing herself and looking into LADY JOHN 'S face .Let 's be fair . Each woman knows why that allegiance died .LADY JOHN turns hastily , sees LORD JOHN coming down with MR. FREDDY and meets them at the foot of the stairs . MISS LEVERING has turned to the table looking for her gloves , & c ., among the papers ; unconsciously drops the handkerchief she had in her little book .JEANin a low voice to MISS LEVERINGAll this talk against the wicked Suffragettes — it makes me want to go and hear what they 've got to say for themselves .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: smiling with a non-committal air as she finds the veil she 's been searching forWell , they 're holding a meeting in Trafalgar Square at three o'clock .

lg.l: This afternoon ? But that 's no use to people out of town ——
Unless I could invent some excuse ....

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: benevolentlyStill talking over the Shelter plans ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: No . We left the Shelter some time ago .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: to JEANThen what 's all the chatterment about ?

div.stage: JEAN , a little confused , looks at MISS LEVERING .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: The latest thing in veils .Ties hers round her hat .

sp.speaker: GREAT
sp.p: The invincible frivolity of woman !

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: geniallyDo n't scold them . It 's a very proper topic .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: whimsicallyOh , I was afraid you 'd despise us for it . BOTH MENwith condescensionNot at all — not at all . JEANto MISS LEVERING as FOOTMAN appearsOh , they 're coming for you . Do n't forget your book .FOOTMAN holds out a salver with a telegram on it for JEAN .Why , it 's for me !

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: But it 's time I was ——Crosses to table .JEANopening the telegramMay I ?Reads , and glances over the paper at MISS LEVERING .I 've got your book .Crosses to MISS LEVERING , and , looking at the back of the volumeDante ! Whereabouts are you ?Opening at the marker .Oh , the “ Inferno . ”

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: No ; I 'm in a worse place .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I did n't know there was a worse .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Yes ; it 's worse with the Vigliacchi .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I forget . Were they Guelf or Ghibelline ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: smilingThey were n't either , and that was why Dante could n't stand them .More gravely .He said there was no place in Heaven nor in Purgatory — not even a corner in Hell — for the souls who had stood aloof from strife .Looking steadily into the girl 's eyes .He called them “ wretches who never lived , ” Dante did , because they 'd never felt the pangs of partizanship . And so they wander homeless on the skirts of limbo among the abortions and off-scourings of Creation . JEANa long breath after a long look . When MISS LEVERING has turned away to make her leisurely adieux JEAN 'S eyes fall on the open telegramAunt Ellen , I 've got to go to London .

div.stage: STONOR , re-entering , hears this , but pretends to talk to MR. FREDDY , & c .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: My dear child !

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Nonsense ! Is your grandfather worse ? JEANfolding the telegramNo-o . I do n't think so . But it 's necessary I should go , all the same .

sp.speaker: MRS. H
sp.p: Go away when Mr. Stonor ——

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: He said he 'd have to leave directly after luncheon .

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: I 'll just see Miss Levering off , and then I 'll come back and talk about it .

sp.speaker: LORD J
sp.p: to MISS LEVERINGWhy are you saying goodbye as if you were never coming back ?

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: smilingOne never knows . Maybe I sha n't come back .To STONOR .Goodbye .STONOR bows ceremoniously . The others go up laughing . STONOR comes down .JEANimpulsivelyThere may n't be another train ! Miss Levering —— STONORstanding in front of herWhat if there is n't ? I 'll take you back in the motor . JEANrapturouslyWill you ?Inadvertently drops the telegram .I must be there by three ! STONORpicks up the telegram and a handkerchief lying near , glances at the messageWhy , it 's only an invitation to dine — Wednesday !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Sh !Takes the telegram and puts it in her pocket .

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Oh , I see !Lower , smiling .It 's rather dear of you to arrange our going off like that . You are a clever little girl !

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: It 's not that I was arranging . I want to hear those women in Trafalgar Square — the Suffragettes . STONORincredulous , but smilingHow perfectly absurd !Looking after LADY JOHN .Besides , I expect she would n't like my carrying you off like that .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Then she 'll have to make an excuse and come too .

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Ah , it would n't be quite the same —— JEANrapidly thinking it outWe could get back here in time for dinner .GEOFFREY STONOR glances down at the handkerchief still in his hand , and turns it half mechanically from corner to corner .JEANabsent-mindedlyMine ? STONORhastily , without reflectionNo .Hands it to MISS LEVERING as she passes .Yours .MISS LEVERING , on her way to the lobby with LORD JOHN seems not to notice .JEANtakes the handkerchief to give to her , glancing down at the embroidered corner ; stopsBut that 's not an L ! sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: Yes ; I 'm coming .

div.stage: Exit MISS LEVERING .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I did n't know her name was Vida ; how did you ?

div.stage: STONOR stares silently over the top of his paper .
CURTAIN .

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: SCENE : The north side of the Nelson Column in Trafalgar Square . The Curtain rises on an uproar . The crowd , which momentarily increases , is composed chiefly of weedy youths and wastrel old men . There are a few decent artisans ; three or four “ beery ” out-o ’ - works ; three or four young women of the domestic servant or Strand restaurant cashier class ; one aged woman in rusty black peering with faded , wondering eyes , consulting the faces of the men and laughing nervously and apologetically from time to time ; one or two quiet-looking , business-like women , thirty to forty ; two middle-class men , who stare and whisper and smile . A quiet old man with a lot of unsold Sunday papers under one arm stands in an attitude of rapt attention , with the free hand round his deaf ear . A brisk-looking woman of forty-five or so , wearing pince-nez , goes round with a pile of propagandist literature on her arm . Many of the men smoking cigarettes — the old ones pipes . On the outskirts of this crowd , of several hundred , a couple of smart men in tall shining hats hover a few moments , single eyeglass up , and then saunter off . Against the middle of the Column , where it rises above the stone platform , is a great red banner , one supporting pole upheld by a grimy sandwichman , the other by a small , dirty boy of eight . If practicable only the lower portion of the banner need be seen , bearing the final words of the legend —

in immense white letters . It will be well to get , to the full , the effect of the height above the crowd of the straggling group of speakers on the pedestal platform . These are , as the Curtain rises , a working-class woman who is waving her arms and talking very earnestly , her voice for the moment blurred in the uproar . She is dressed in brown serge and looks pinched and sallow . At her side is the CHAIRMAN urging that she be given a fair hearing . ALLEN TRENT is a tall , slim , brown-haired man of twenty-eight , with a slight stoop , an agreeable aspect , well-bred voice , and the gleaming brown eye of the visionary . Behind these two , looking on or talking among themselves , are several other carelessly dressed women ; one , better turned out than the rest , is quite young , very slight and gracefully built , with round , very pink cheeks , full , scarlet lips , naturally waving brown hair , and an air of childish gravity . She looks at the unruly mob with imperturbable calm . The CHAIRMAN 'S voice is drowned .

div.stage: Applause , chiefly ironic , laughter , a general moving closer and knitting up of attention . ERNESTINE BLUNT is about twenty-four , but looks younger . She is very downright , not to say pugnacious — the something amusing and attractive about her is there , as it were , against her will , and the more fetching for that . She has no conventional gestures , and none of any sort at first . As she warms to her work she uses her slim hands to enforce her emphasis , but as though unconsciously . Her manner of speech is less monotonous than that of the average woman-speaker , but she , too , has a fashion of leaning all her weight on the end of the sentence . She brings out the final word or two with an effort of underscoring , and makes a forward motion of the slim body as if the better to drive the last nail in . She evidently means to be immensely practical — the kind who is pleased to think she has n't a grain of sentimentality in her composition , and whose feeling , when it does all but master her , communicates itself magnetically to others .

sp.p: Now , there 's another woman going to speak .

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh , is she ? Who ? Which ? I do hope she 'll be one of the wild ones .

sp.p: speaking through this last . sp.p: Not yet — oh , please not yet .Breathless , looking back .Why I — I do believe —— STONORto LADY JOHN , with decisionI 'm going to take JEAN out of this mob . Will you come ?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: What ? Oh yes , if you think ——Another look through her glasses .But is n't that — surely its ——!! !

sp.p: Oh ! oh !

sp.p: Now , I ask you to listen , as quietly as you can , to a lady who is not accustomed to speaking — a — in Trafalgar Square — or a ... as a matter of fact , at all .

sp.p: A lady who , as I 've said , will tell you , if you 'll behave yourselves , her impressions of the administration of police-court justice in this country .

She flushes , comes quite to the edge of the platform and raises her voice a little .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I just wanted to tell you that I was — I was — present in the police-court when the women were charged for creating a disturbance .

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: Y ’ ought n't t ’ get mixed up in wot did n't concern you .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: I — I ——Stumbles and stops .Talking and laughing increases . “ Wot 's ‘ er name ? ” “ Mrs. or Miss ? ” “ Ai n't seen this one before . ”CHAIRMANanxiouslyNow , see here , men ; do n't interrupt —— A GIRLshrillyI like this one 's ‘ at . Ye can see she ai n't one of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.p: trying to recommenceI ——

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: They 're a disgrace — them women be'ind yer .

sp.speaker: A MAN WITH A FATHERLY AIR

lg.l: It 's the w'y they goes on as mykes the
Government keep ye from gettin ’ yer rights .
It 's the way you go on that ——
